Steve Bakunas (2005-present) |alma_mater = [[College of William and Mary|College of William and Mary]] }} '''Linda Lavin''' (born October 15, 1937) is an [[United States|American]] singer and actress. She is best known for playing the title character in the [[situation comedy|sitcom]] ''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]'' and for her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] performances. After acting as a child, Lavin joined the [[Compass Players]] in the late 1950s. She began acting on Broadway in the 1960s, earning notice by 1966 in ''[[It's a Bird...It's a Plane...It's Superman]]'' 1966 and receiving her first [[Tony Award]] nomination in ''[[Last of the Red Hot Lovers]]'' in 1970. She moved to [[Hollywood]] in 1973 and began to work in television, making recurring appearances on ''[[Barney Miller]]'' before getting the title role in ''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]'', which ran from 1976 to 1985. She appeared in many [[telefilm]]s and later in other TV work. She has also had roles in several feature films. In 1987, she returned to Broadway, starring in ''[[Broadway Bound]]'' (winning a [[Tony Award]]), ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' (1990), ''[[The Sisters Rosensweig]]'' (1993), ''[[The Diary of Anne Frank (play)|The Diary of Anne Frank]]'' (1997â1998) and ''[[The Tale of the Allergist's Wife]]'' (2000â2001), among others. In 2010, she appeared as Ruth Steiner in ''[[Collected Stories (play)|Collected Stories]]'', garnering her fifth Tony nomination. Thrice married, Lavin spends time at her [[North Carolina]] home on charitable activities. == Early life and career == Lavin was born in [[Portland, Maine|Portland]], [[Maine]], the daughter of Lucille (nÃ©e Potter), an opera singer, and David J. Lavin, a businessman.[http://www.filmreference.com/film/0/Linda-Lavin.html "Linda Lavin Biography"]. FilmReference.com, accessed October 15, 2010 Her family was musically talented, and Lavin has been onstage since the age of five.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} Upon her graduation from the [[College of William and Mary]],Embry, Ingerline Voosen.[http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/lavin-linda "Linda Lavin biography"] Jewish Women's Archive, retrieved October 15, 2010 she had already received her [[Actors' Equity Association]] card. She was a member of the [[Compass Players]] in the late 1950s.Yearwood, Pauline Dubkin. [http://www.chicagojewishnews.com/story.htm?sid=3&id=253486 "In the beginning: As Second City marks 50 years, a look at its Jewish founders and Jewish stars"]. Chicagojewishnews.com, December 11, 2009 By the early 1960s, Lavin had appeared in several [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] shows and appeared on the 1966 [[cast recording]]s of ''[[The Mad Show]]'' performing Stephen Sondheim's "[[The Boy From...]]". From ''[[It's a Bird...It's a Plane...It's Superman]]'', one of her numbers, "You've Got Possibilities," was the album's best-received song and was called "The one memorable song...flirty, syncopated" by the ''Dallas Observer''.Liner, Elaine. [http://www.dallasobserver.com/2010-07-01/culture/in-the-dallas-theater-center-s-super-fun-superman-musical-you-don-t-need-x-ray-vision-to-see-deeper-themes/ Superman Musical, You Don't Need X-Ray Vision To See Deeper Themes"]. ''Dallas Observer'', July 1, 2010 == Career == === Television and film === In 1967, Lavin made an appearance as Gloria Thorpe in a television version of the [[Musical film|musical]] ''[[Damn Yankees]]'' with [[Phil Silvers]].Hischak, Thomas S.[http://books.google.com/books?id=XbBz3C4Gr0EC&pg=PA183&lpg=PA183&dq=%22Damn+Yankees%22+%22Linda+Lavin%22&source=bl&ots=9lLrjuXt_w&sig=wPGxO-vlkvNVK14CWyX5VLOqrhg&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22Damn%20Yankees%22%20%22Linda%20Lavin%22&f=false "'Damn Yankees' Casts"] ''The Oxford Companion to the American Musical'', Oxford University Press US, 2008, ISBN 0195335333, p. 183 In 1969, Lavin married actor [[Ron Leibman]],[http://www.filmreference.com/film/31/Ron-Leibman.html Leibman biography]. filmreference.com, retrieved October 15, 2010 and by 1973 the couple had arrived in [[Hollywood]], California. After various guest appearances on episodic television series such as ''[[The Nurses (CBS TV series)|The Nurses]]'', ''[[Rhoda]]'', ''[[Harry O (TV series)|Harry O]]'' and ''[[Kaz (TV series)|Kaz]]'', Lavin landed a recurring role on ''[[Barney Miller]]'' during the first and second seasons (1975â1976).[http://classicsitcoms.com/shows/barney1.html "'Barney Liller', see March 13, 1975"]. classicsitcoms.com, accessed June 20, 2011 She left ''Barney Miller'' to star in the lead role in ''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]''. The show was a popular hit for [[CBS]] and ran from 1976 to 1985. The series was based on the [[Martin Scorsese]]-directed [[Ellen Burstyn]] film ''[[Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore]]''.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0073955/ Internet Movie Database listing, 'Alice'"]. imdb.com, retrieved October 15, 2010 Lavin portrayed [[Alice Hyatt]], a waitress and singer, the character that Burstyn had played. Lavin performed the series' theme song, "There's a New Girl in Town," which was written by [[David Shire]] and [[Alan Bergman|Alan]] and [[Marilyn Bergman]] [http://www.alanandmarilynbergman.com/works-tv-title.htm "Alan & Marilyn Bergman Songs In Television"]. alanandmarilynbergman.com, accessed June 21, 2011 and was updated for each of the first six seasons. During the series' nine-season run, Lavin earned two [[Golden Globe]] awards and an [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] nomination,Terrece, Vincent. [http://books.google.com/books?id=AKlgjBCPPnsC&pg=PA10&dq=Alice++%22Linda+Lavin%22+television&hl=en#v=onepage&q=Alice%20%20%22Linda%20Lavin%22%20television&f=false "'Alice' listing"]. ''Encyclopedia of Television Series, Pilots and Specials: 1974-1984'' (1985), VNR AG, ISBN 0918432618, pp. 9-10 and gained experience directing, especially during the later seasons. Lavin also played a dual role in "Alice", as Debbie Walden, the wizened and former landlady of the character [[Vera Louise Gorman-Novak]].[http://www.blockbuster.com/browse/catalog/personDetails/36025 "Linda Lavin Movies, see 'Alice'"]. blockbuster.com, accessed June 20, 2011 Lavin also made numerous television appearances outside of ''Alice'', including hosting her own holiday special, ''Linda in Wonderland''. She acted in two sitcoms, 1992's ''[[Room for Two]]'' and 1998's ''[[Conrad Bloom]]''.[http://www.tvguide.com/detail/tv-show.aspx?tvobjectid=100095&more=ucepisodelist&episodeid=941894 "'Conrad Bloom' Episodes"]. tvguide.com, accessed June 20, 2011 She made numerous television guest appearances, including roles on ''[[The Muppet Show]]'', ''[[Law & Order: Criminal Intent]]'', ''[[The O.C.]]'', ''[[Touched by an Angel]]'' and [[HBO]]'s ''[[The Sopranos]]''. She also appeared in many [[telefilm]]s between 1967 and 1998, including: ''Damn Yankees!'', ''Sadbird'', ''[[The Morning After (1974 film)|The Morning After]]'', ''Jerry'', ''[[Like Mom, Like Me]]'', ''The $5.20 an Hour Dream'', ''A Matter of Life and Death'', ''Another Woman's Child'', ''Maricela'', ''Lena: My 100 Children'', ''Whitewash'', ''A Dream is a Wish Your Heart Makes: The [[Annette Funicello]] Story'', ''[[Stolen Memories: Secrets from the Rose Garden]]'', ''For the Future: The Irvine Fertility Scandal'', ''The Ring'', and ''Best Friends for Life''.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0386467/ "'Flour Babies' Internet Movie Database listing"]. imdb.com, retrieved October 15, 2010 She directed the 1990 telefilm ''[[Flour Babies]]''.[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/460797/Flour-Babies/ "'Flour Babies' Listing"]. tcm.com, accessed June 21, 2011 Lavin made her feature film debut in ''[[The Muppets Take Manhattan]]'' (1984).[http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/152583%7C0/The-Muppets-Take-Manhattan.html "'The Muppets Take Manhattan' Listing"]. tcm.com, accessed June 20, 2011 Her other feature film appearances include ''[[See You in the Morning (film)|See You in the Morning]]'', starring [[Jeff Bridges]],Canby, Vincent. [http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=950DE4DA173EF932A15757C0A96F948260 "Movie Review: 'See You in the Morning'"]. ''New York Times'', April 21, 1989 [[Alain Resnais]]'s ''[[I Want to Go Home (film)|I Want to Go Home]]'', opposite [[Gerard Depardieu]] (both 1989),Croce, Fernando. [http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/i-want-to-go-home/3399 "'I Want to Go Home'"]. ''Slant Magazine'', February 28, 2008 and ''[[The Back-Up Plan]]'' (2010).[http://www.pbs.org/hollywoodpresents/collectedstories/roles/roles_lavin.html "Linda Lavin Biography"]. pbs.org, accessed June 20, 2011 === Theatre === Lavin began her career with [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] appearances in the musicals ''[[A Family Affair (musical)|A Family Affair]]'' (1962) and ''[[On a Clear Day You Can See Forever]]'' (1966), and plays such as ''The Riot Act'' (1963), ''Something Different'' (1967) and ''Cop Out'' (1969). She "arrived at showbiz stardom with a featured role" in the musical ''[[It's a Bird...It's a Plane...It's Superman]]'' (1966).[http://books.google.com/books?id=MuECAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA97&dq=It's-a-Bird-It's-a-Plane-It's-Superman+%22Linda+Lavin%22&hl=en#v=onepage&q=It's-a-Bird-It's-a-Plane-It's-Superman%20%22Linda%20Lavin%22&f=false "Nightlife" listings]. Broadway.com, May 3, 2010 Her first [[Tony Award]] nomination was for her role in the [[Neil Simon]] play, ''[[Last of the Red Hot Lovers]]'' in 1970.[http://sanfrancisco.broadwayworld.com/tonyawardsyear.cfm?year=1970 "1970 Tony Awards"] broadwayworld.com, accessed June 21, 2011 Lavin's last Broadway credit before she moved to [[Hollywood, Los Angeles, California|Hollywood]] was in ''[[Paul Sills' Story Theatre]]'' in 1971. In her early years, Lavin also appeared in numerous [[Off-Broadway]] productions, including ''Wet Paint'' (1965), the musical ''[[The Mad Show]]'' (1966)[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&id=3935 Internet Off-Broadway database listing, "'The Mad Show'"]. Internet Off-Broadway Database, retrieved October 15, 2010 and ''Little Murders'' (1969). Lavin won the [[Theatre World Award]] for ''Wet Paint''[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&id=4038 Internet Off-Broadway database listing, 'Wet Paint'"] Internet Off-Broadway Database, retrieved October 15, 2010 and a [[Drama Desk Award]] for ''Little Murders''.[http://www.dramadesk.com/1968_1969dd.html "Drama Desk Awards, 1968-1969]. Dramadesk.com, retrieved October 15, 2010[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=show&id=2500 Internet Off-Broadway database listing, "'Little Murders'"]. Internet Off-Broadway Database, retrieved October 15, 2010 After more than a decade away, during which she appeared on television, Lavin returned to the Broadway stage in 1987, winning a [[Tony Award]] and her second [[Drama Desk Award]] for her role as Kate in Simon's play ''[[Broadway Bound]]''.[http://sanfrancisco.broadwayworld.com/tonyawardsyear.cfm?year=1987 "Tony Awards, 1987"] broadwayworld.com, accessed June 21, 2011 [[Frank Rich]], in his ''[[New York Times]]'' review, wrote: "One only wishes that Ms. Lavin, whose touching performance is of the same high integrity as the writing, could stay in the role forever."Rich, Frank. [http://theater.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9A0DE1D7113AF936A35751C1A960948260 "Theater: Simon's 'Broadway Bound'"]''New York Times'', December 5, 1986 She then starred on Broadway in ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' as Mama Rose Hovick (1990).Rich, Frank.[http://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/theater/review-theater-linda-lavin-takes-her-turn-as-mama-rose.html "Review/Theater; Linda Lavin Takes Her Turn as Mama Rose"] ''New York Times'', September 18, 1990 [[June Havoc]] saw Lavin's performance in ''Gypsy'' and sent Lavin a photo of Havoc's mother, the real Rose Hovick, with a note of appreciation for Lavin's particular portrayal of the character.[http://www.aislesay.com/FTR-LAVIN.html]. Aislesay.com Subsequent Broadway roles included Gorgeous Teitelbaum in ''[[The Sisters Rosensweig]]'' (1993) and Mrs. Van Daan in ''[[The Diary of Anne Frank (play)|The Diary of Anne Frank]]'' (1997â1998), opposite [[Natalie Portman]], for which she garnered another Tony nomination as Featured Actress in a Play.[http://sanfrancisco.broadwayworld.com/tonyawardsyear.cfm?year=1998 "Tony Awards, 1998"] broadwayworld.com, accessed June 21, 2011 She played Marjorie in ''[[The Tale of the Allergist's Wife]]'' (2000â2001), co-starring [[Tony Roberts (actor)|Tony Roberts]] and [[Michele Lee]], for which she was nominated for the Tony Award, Actress in a Play[http://sanfrancisco.broadwayworld.com/tonyawardsyear.cfm?year=2001 "Tony Awards, 2001"] broadwayworld.com, accessed June 21, 2011 and Drama Desk Award, and the nanny in ''[[Hollywood Arms]]''. Off-Broadway, she was nominated for a Drama Desk Award for her performance in ''Death-Defying Acts'', a play for which she also won a Best Actress [[Obie Award]] and the [[Lucille Lortel Award]]. In 2010, Lavin appeared as Ruth Steiner in a Broadway revival of the play ''[[Collected Stories (play)|Collected Stories]]'',Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/138569-Lavin-Paulson-Star-in-Collected-Stories-Making-Broadway-Bow-April-9 "Lavin & Paulson Star in Collected Stories, Making Broadway Bow April 9"]. She appeared in the new play by [[Jon Robin Baitz]], ''Other Desert Cities'', [[Off-Broadway]] at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater ([[Lincoln Center]]) beginning in previews in December 2010, closing February 27, 2011.[http://www.lct.org/showMain.htm?id=201 " 'Desert Cities' Listing"] Lincoln Center, accessed May 29, 2011 Lavin appeared in the [[Kennedy Center]] (Washington, DC) production of the musical ''[[Follies]]'', from May 2011 to June 2011, as Hattie Walker.Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150498-Hats-Off-Here-They-Come-Those-Beautiful-Girls-Starry-Follies-Begins-Kennedy-Center-Run-May-7 "Hats Off, Here They Come, Those Beautiful Girls": Starry Follies Begins Kennedy Center Run May 7"]. Playbill.com, May 7, 2011 She is currently starring in the premiere of the [[Nicky Silver]] play ''The Lyons'' at the Off-Broadway Vineyard Theatre, which opened on October 11, 2011 and is running through October 30.Brantley, Ben.[http://theater.nytimes.com/2011/10/12/theater/reviews/the-lyons-by-nicky-silver-at-vineyard-theater-review.html "Theater Review:The Curse of Kinship, but a Fear of Isolation"] ''The New York Times'', October 11, 2011 ===Other work=== Lavin performed a cabaret act at [[Birdland (jazz club)|Birdland]] in August 2005, with one reviewer noting, "Her nightclub act is a rewarding, sometimes revealing, and thoroughly entertaining visit."Lester, Rob. [http://www.talkinbroadway.com/cabaret/083105.html "Linda Lavin Soars at Birdland"]. talkinbroadway.com, August 31, 2005, accessed June 21, 2011 She performed her act at the Plush Room, San Francisco, with Billy Stritch and her husband Steve Bakunas in September 2005.Connema, Richard. [http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/sanfran/s679.html "Linda Lavin is the Life of the Party"]. talkinbroadway.com, September 17, 2005, accessed June 21, 2011 She performed at Feinstein's at the Regency, New York in March 2006.Gans, Andrew. She is giving a concert to celebrate the CD at Birdland in December 2011.Gans, Andrew. [http://tunes.broadwayworld.com/article/Ghostlight-Records-Releases-Linda-Lavins-New-Album-Possibilities-1129-20111128]. tunes.broadwayworld.com, November 29, 2011 == Personal life == Lavin has been married three times. Her first marriage to [[Ron Leibman]] ended in divorce in 1980. Her second marriage to Kip Niven, who played Steve Marsh, the boyfriend of [[Vera Louise Gorman-Novak]] on ''Alice'', ended in divorce in 1992.Brozan, Nadine.[http://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/03/style/chronicle-471292.html "Chronicle"]''New York Times'', July 03, 1992 While Lavin has no biological children, she is the stepmother to Niven's children Jim and Kate Niven and the grandmother to Jim's sons Grayson and Talen. Lavin married actor, artist and musician Steve Bakunas in 2005.Key, Lindsay. [http://www.wrightsvillebeachmagazine.com/article.asp?aid=599&iid=76 "The Art of Love"]. Wrightsville Beach Magazine, February 2010 The couple resides in [[Wilmington, North Carolina]] where they are committed community members working together to rehabilitate impoverished neighborhoods, including renovating many homes, donating a park to the city and creating a [[community theater]], the Red Barn Studio.[http://redbarnstudiotheatre.com/ "Red Barn Studio"]. redbarnstudiotheatre.com, accessed June 20, 2011 In 1997, Lavin founded The Linda Lavin Arts Foundation in Wilmington, "to promote and foster the advancement of the performing and visual arts, with special emphasis on arts in education. Her foundation has created a theatre program called Girl Friends, whose purpose is to raise the self-esteem of at-risk teenage girls of the inner city." In Wilmington, she directs for the stage. Innovations as a director included a 1998 production of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[As You Like It]]'' performed in a [[Brazil]]ian [[jazz]] style. In both Wilmington and New York she teaches master classes in acting and singing. ==Awards== Lavin was inducted into the [[American Theatre Hall of Fame]] for 2010 in January 2011.Gans, Andrew and
